text: To go in French, to go, is aller.
How would you say I can go there?
Je peux aller là.
Now, you could say that in French if you were pointing or gesturing towards something,
but the French tend not to use there in that sense so often.
Perhaps what's more often used is something like over there, so we'll start with that.
How would you say I can go there, but literally saying I can go over there?
Je peux aller là-bas.
I can go over there this evening.
Je peux aller là-bas ce soir.
I can go over there this evening, but he can't go over there.
How would you say that?
Let's start with I can go over there this evening.
Je peux aller là-bas ce soir.
But he can't go over there.
Mais il ne peut pas aller là-bas.
How would you say I want to go over there?
Je veux aller là-bas.
You want to go over there.
You want to go over there?
You want to go over there?
How would you say do you want to go over there?
Voulez-vous aller là-bas?
Let's see which other ways we could use to ask the same question.
Let's try it using is it that at the beginning and saying is it that you want to go over there?
Est-ce que vous voulez aller là-bas?
Finally, let's try using the rising intonation and say you want to go over there?
Vous voulez aller là-bas?
Reply yes.
I want to go over there now.
Oui, je veux aller là-bas maintenant.
How would you say I want to prepare the dinner?
Je veux préparer le dîner.
How would you say I want to prepare it?
Je veux le préparer.
Now, you'll notice that when we say I want to prepare the dinner,
the dinner goes afterwards as it does in English.
We say I want to prepare the dinner.
But when we replace the dinner with it, it goes before.
Because I want to prepare it was...
What was it again?
Je veux le préparer.
As you can see, the le does not go after préparer,
although that's a common mistake English speakers will make.
In order to explain this more clearly,
I'm going to introduce a grammatical term,
which is something I don't do unless I absolutely have to.
However, I'm going to explain it in a way that everyone can understand.
I'm going to use the term noun.
Now, typically, a noun is described as something like a person, place or thing.
But it's not very specific and not very helpful because a lot of nouns are not covered by that.
For instance, something like the happiness or difficulty.
That's not really a person, place or thing in their most obvious senses.
I prefer to define a noun by simply saying it's a word you can put my in front of.
If you can put my immediately in front of a word and it makes sense, it is a noun.
So, my happiness, my difficulties, my dog, my house, my name.
You can put my in front of them sensibly and you know then that it's a noun.
You can't put my in front of a verb.
It won't work.
You can't say my to walk, my to sleep.
It sounds crazy.
You can't say my happy, my joyful.
But you can say my joy and that tells you that it's a noun.
So, it's a very easy, very quick way to identify a noun is simply see can you put my directly in front of it.
Okay.
Now, you may be wondering why I'm bringing up what a noun is at all.
Well, let's look at the dinner.
Can we say my dinner?
Well, we can.
It's quite possible to say my dinner.
My dinner is cold.
My dinner is not ready.
So, dinner is therefore a noun.
Now, let's try the dinner in that sentence again.
How would you say I want to prepare the dinner?
How would you say I want to prepare it?
Je veux le préparer.
How would you say I want to prepare the dinner?
How would you say I want to prepare the dinner?
I want to prepare the dinner.
I want to prepare the dinner.
How would you say I want to prepare the dinner?
How would you say I want to prepare the dinner?
How would you say I want to prepare the dinner?
How would you say I want to prepare the dinner?
How would you say I want to prepare the dinner?
